div.ab: Man: O, Death, be not thou boastful, over the just: the sons of thy Lord who at His command, come to dwell with thee.
Response: To thee be glory that by Thy command, Death has reigned: and by Thy Resurrection has been humbled to low estate!
Death., Herein am I exceeding great, according to thy saying: that though I be bond-man I trample on them that are free.
Man: Adam was chosen and ruler, and under his yoke: thou, Death, and the Evil One, thy fellow, became bondmen.
Death: This is our pride that lo! the slaves have become lords: Death, and Satan, his fellow, have trampled on Adam.
Man: Lo! the humbling of thee and thy fellow, accurst servants! how Enoch trampled on you both, and rose aloft and reigned.
Death: If so be Enoch made me grieve, yet have I comfort for on Noah’s dust in Sheol, lo! I trample.
Man: Tremble, O Death, before man, for though a servant, the yoke of his dominion reigns on all creatures.
Death: I rejoice then that they are no mean foes that I have overcome: for according to the greatness of the vanquished, he is great that overcomes.
Man: Well does thy voice sing triumph, O Death, over the just: for Enoch and Elijah have broken thy pair of wings.
Death: I know how to weigh my sorrows with my comforts: in place of two, lo! many are come and coming.
Man: All that are come and coming to thee dwell as sojourners, and depart from thy abode as Lazarus.
Death: This thy saying hurts me not, rather it heals me: for Lazarus who rebelled against me, I again subdued.
Man: Make answer, O Death, and argue what constrained him, to be raised unless it were a mystery, showing forth his resurrection.
Death: Ye are famous in arguing as idle ones, while I labour in my task to discern and perform
Man: Thou wast well prepared for argument, what has checked thee? The truth of our resurrection has constrained thee by its reputations.
Death: Ye have made me hated by you, though I be not hateful: I am he that gives rest to your aged, and your afflicted.
Ye have made me as one that troubles, O ye mortals: Adam brought death upon you, and I bear the blame.
Gently will I expose you, for I am a slave, and ye are they that by your sins have made me king.
The will of Adam roused me for I was at rest: I was dead and ye quickened me, that ye might die by me.
I accuse the lying ones, who slew and denied it: for Adam slew himself and charges me.
The beginning of strife was the accursed serpent which has rightly been crippled: which crept, entered, and set enmity between me and you.
Satan is passed by and it is against me that ye are roused: go, strive with the Evil One who made you transgress.
He is my comrade and I deny it not, but though he be much hated, what need that I be blamed for him. I deny him henceforth.
Hearken to my words, O mortals, and I will console you: I have afflicted you and I confess the life from the dead.
For there begins to steal into my ears a voice of preparation: of the trumpet that holds itself ready to sound.
Hear my words and put much oil into your lamps: for hindrance from my part there is none for you.
Yet, Know ye that even although I have said these things, dear is the sound of your voice in the solitude of Sheol.
For man has been weighed by me, and great is his peace: for snakes and fishes and birds come to meet him.
But it is a marvel that to the Watchers, too, his converse is dear: yea, the Evil One in Gehenna, desires his presence.
Ye shall have life from the dead, O ye mortals, and I who am bereft shall be bereft in the midst of Sheol.
Let praise ascend from all to Thee Who quickenest all, and from every quarter gatherest the dust of Adam!
